caseTitle: NANA KOFI OWUSU v KWAKU OWUSU ANSAH & BAFFOUR APPIAH DANKWA
summary: This 2007 Supreme Court of Ghana judgment in Nana Kofi Owusu v Kwaku Owusu Ansah & Baffour Appiah Dankwa concerns a land dispute over Twedie lands designated as Durbar Grounds. The High Court had granted an interim injunction to preserve the status quo, which the Court of Appeal overturned, finding the plaintiff had a stronger claim based on historical arbitrations favoring Toasehene's ownership. The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appealâ€™s decision, ruling that the trial judge misapplied facts by citing non-existent pending litigation and failed to properly assess pleadings and affidavits. The court emphasized that interim injunctions must be based on a serious question to be tried and balanced hardship, concluding the plaintiff would suffer greater harm if development of communal land was restrained. The judgment also highlighted the importance of environmental and communal land conservation.
citations: Thorne v. British Broadcasting Corporation [1957] 1 WLR 1104
American Cyanamid Co. v. Ethicon Ltd. [1975] 1 All E.R. 504
rationaleHighlights: The trial judge erred by relying on a supposed pending litigation that was not supported by the record.
An interim injunction requires a serious question to be tried and protection of legal rights, not mere assertion.
The Court of Appeal properly considered pleadings and affidavits showing Toasehene's historical ownership.
Hardship to the plaintiff in blocking community development outweighed claimed revenue loss by defendant.
Discretion in granting injunctions must be based on proper and relevant evidence.
The plaintiff was acting as agent of Toasehene, whose ownership was upheld by prior arbitration awards.
Revenue from the land was to be shared among traditional authorities, undermining defendant's financial claim.
Environmental and communal interests support development of public durbar grounds.
